results.title: Who wants to be a princess anyway?
results.creator_credit: Susan Cornwell, Tristram Miall and Film Australia
results.brief_description: Why do boys receive more attention in the classroom than girls do? This video examines a gender equity program operating in primary schools to encourage girls to develop an awareness of the range of career and educational options available to them, in particular, in the fields of maths and science. Some classes in a co-educational primary school are conducted as single-sex classes to develop the confidence of the girls.

results.title: Who sold you this then? (NP)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Marketing in Practice”.
John Cleese is Charlie Jenkins, the Service Engineer. The film shows how he can destroy the reputation of his company and its products every time he talks to a customer. It also shows how he could be his company’s best ambassador. It is an object lesson for everyone in the company who has to deal directly with customers.

results.title: Who should decide?
results.creator_credit: Beverly Shaffer, Wolf Koenig, Andy Thomson and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “A Discussion in bioethics”.
One of a series of short, open-ended dramas designed to stimulate discussion of values and ethics in relation to modern medical technology. This film deals with questions arising from advances in pre-natal diagnosis. Joanne, a victim of spina bifida, discovers that her unborn child has the same disease. A decision whether to terminate the pregnancy must be reached quickly. When her husband says that all he ever wanted was “a normal baby,” Joanne counters with “What is normal?”
results.creator_credit_for_label: Beverly Shaffer, Wolf Koenig, Andy Thomson and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: Who shall ease the pain?
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “W5”.
This film argues the case that there is no need for cancer sufferers to die in pain. The triumvirate of drugs cocaine, heroin and marijuana alone or a mixture combination may be recommended to ease pain. The illicit use of these drugs has detracted the possibilities of their potential to be put to good use. One man alone in the USA has medical and legal prescriptions for 10 marijuana cigarettes per day to prevent blindness.

results.title: Who robbed the robins?
results.brief_description: A delightful animated story: A family of robins have their eggs stolen by another bird. Father robin hires a detective to recover their eggs. The eggs are returned safely to mother and father robin and the villain is taken into custody. The three eggs hatch and the robin family live happily ever after. Animation by H.J Whitaker. Music composed and orchestrated by Jose Norman. Designed by Alan Carter.

results.title: Who protects the worker?
results.creator_credit: Graham Massey, Michael Latham and Video Arts
results.brief_description:
Episode number 8 of Series “Free to choose”.
Trade unions, claims Milton Friedman, benefit members at other workers’ expense; government employees gain higher wages at the expense of the taxpayer. Higher wages and better working conditions would result from a free labor market. Suitable for middle and upper secondary, and tertiary levels.

results.title: Who protects the consumer?
results.creator_credit: Graham Massey, Michael Latham and Video Arts
results.brief_description:
Episode number 7 of Series “Free to choose”.
Milton Friedman disputes the view that consumers need governmental protection against the business community and that government actions tend to make consumers better off. The best protection, he claims, is the free market where consumers will desert inferior products or sevices. Suitable for middle and upper secondary, and tertiary levels.

results.title: Who pays the price?
results.creator_credit: Peter Wilkinson and Australian Broadcasting Commission
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Work that was”.
One of a 3 part series on unemployment in Australia, presented by Keith Windschuttle. Examines the role of new technology in displacing people from traditional jobs. Shows how silicon chips are made, and their current and future applications in traditionally labour intensive areas such as retailing, banking and office work. Looks at the possible social effects of technological change in the context of Australia’s economic system.
